overview.short: Vibrio vulnificus is a highly virulent, halophilic, Gram-negative curved rod associated with severe wound infections and fulminant septicemia.
overview.clinical_context: Typically linked to exposure to warm seawater or ingestion of raw seafood; causes rapidly progressive infections, especially in patients with liver disease or immunocompromise.

species_markers.notes: Encapsulated strains are strongly associated with invasive disease and septicemia.
Halophilicity distinguishes V. vulnificus from non-halophilic Vibrios such as V. cholerae.
Variable sucrose fermentation can complicate TCBS interpretation.

common_confusions.reason: Both are halophilic and oxidase-positive; capsule presence and clinical severity help differentiate.
Shared salt tolerance; alginolyticus is typically less invasive and often sucrose-positive.

when_to_question_identification: Lack of salt tolerance argues against V. vulnificus.
Absence of capsule or mucoid colonies reduces likelihood in invasive disease contexts.
Oxidase-negative isolate is inconsistent with Vibrio.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Supports identification and correlates with virulence.
Supports confirmation in severe or outbreak-associated cases.
recommended_next_tests.api_kit: PCR panel targeting vvhA or vcg virulence genes
